title: Nike Men's Air Monarch IV Training/Workout Shoes
Customer_say: Customers find these running shoes comfortable, well-fitting, and good value for money. They receive positive feedback for their appearance and arch support, particularly noting they provide good support for side-to-side motion and walking and working out. The durability receives mixed reviews - while some say they hold up well, others report issues with the rubber separating from the sole. Customers also mention the shoes squeak badly and are very noisy.

Review.review: These are often called "grandpa" shoes because they look a little clunky but they are still the best shoes I have found for exercise classes and basketball in that they are extremely stable through the last and I have not had an ankle turn since I started wearing them yeas ago. The bottoms of my feet are sensitive with minor neuropathy and these shoes fit wonderfully and wrap the foot well. The pivot point is great for people who take a cardio, Jazzercise, Shine, or equivalent class in that it facilitates turns, spins, and rapid direction changes.I do have to get a full size larger in Nike shoes (in all Nike clothes for that matter). After a couple of months of heavy use these Air shoes will start to squeak, often quite loudly, well before they wear out. I simply remove the lining  from the shoes and put baby or other talcum powder into the tiny holes under the lining and work it into the holes. This has served me well for years to stop the squeak and it has the additional benefit of freshening up my shoes.I have tried numerous shoe brands over the years and the only shoe that came close to the comfort and stability of this shoe is the Strutter from Adidas, which is no longer made to my knowledge and didn't last as long anyway.One thing Nike could do better is to more firmlyvsecure the sole to the body of the shoe. The glue used by Nike to secure the rubber part of the sole is the first part of the shoe to fail, especially if these shoes get wet regularly from rain or wet grass or even puddles when going to and from your car and the gym classes. I can normally get 6 to 8 months out of the shoes and I have at least 8 one hour classes of various intensity a week (and I do my best to keep the bottoms dry!).For those who wear orthotics, these shoes take them well whether they are heel focused, toe focused, or cover the whole foot. I now wear Goodfeet orthotics and they are quite comfortable in this shoe.

I recently picked up these amazing shoes for my 11-year-old, who is super picky about both style and comfort. I took a chance and chose them without his input—he usually says no to everything! Imagine my excitement when he opened the box and exclaimed, “Mom, I LOVE these!” He couldn’t stop raving about how comfy they are, and his favorite feature? They’re not just easy to slip on, but they also give him a little extra height with thick but soft soals! If you’re on the hunt for a pair that combines style, true to size, comfort, a boost in height, and lets not forget the colors are deep bright and excellent combination,these Nike shoes are an absolute must-have!

I bought the Nike Air Monarch shoes, and they are amazing! Very comfortable, supportive, and perfect for all-day wear. The fit is true to size, and the quality feels great. Definitely recommend for walking, gym, or everyday use!

And the black is not discreet either. Wish they offered a medium gray version.

title: Under Armour Men's Charged Assert 9 Running Shoe
Customer_say: Customers find these running shoes comfortable, well-designed, and lightweight, offering good value for money. They appreciate the fit, with one customer noting they're available in wide sizes. The durability receives mixed feedback - while some say they're holding up great, others report they wear down quickly. The sizing is also mixed, with some finding them true to size while others say they run small.

Review.review: Honestly one of the best shoes on the market for wide foot people, if your looking to snag a simple set of running sneakers, in my opinion. Here's some in-depth info along with  pro's and con's:TLDR: Great quality shoes for the price, and easy to clean. Recommend to beginner and intermediate runners/hikers, experts may be willing to pay more money for increase of quality.PROs:- Perfect Fit. I usually wear 9.0 wide (USA), so that is what I ordered and it fit perfectly.- Comfort and Ease. I like how comfortable they are and they are easy to slip on and off (if you wish) by the use of the heel pull tab. The tab also prevents the heel from getting bunched in or broken when putting on the shoes, which was a frequent problem with some other brands I have owned in the past.- Easy to Clean, Quality Mesh. I have seen some reviews saying these shoes wear out easily or the mesh is easier to damage. YMMV but I didn't seem to have this issue and I've had these shoes for about a year. IMO I find the mesh to be much more durable than the cloth mesh most sports shoes have these days and much easier to clean, which is essential for anyone like myself, who often hikes or runs in forestry/mud.- Above Average Quality. As for the year timeframe, the 1st set was about 8 months of extreme use, then I purchased a 2nd pair which I've had for about 3 months now. This may seem like a short timeframe to some but for me, I usually have to change shoes every 6 months or less if they are lower quality because they get a lot of mileage and use. I still have the 1st set which I use as "lawn mowing shoes", as they are still usable but the tread does not get much grip/traction anymore for running. I liked them enough to buy that 2nd pair instead of some other brand/model.- Decent Arch Support and Sole Tread. You will find other shoes with the same or better, but I didn't see many that were this cheap in price.- Part of Amazon's "Try Before You Buy". Free try-ons. You can take up to 6 days to decide whether to keep/return if you wish, and only be charged if not returned by the 7th day. Day 1 is the day they are delivered.- Uniform in Color. The shoe currently comes in all-black or all-white, including the logo. YMMV but this is a pro for me due to work restrictions requiring all-black shoes, so I can also wear them leisurely at work if I choose (I'm a mechanic). Great for anyone with the same issue, or military, etc.CONs:- Not the most expert/elite quality shoe out there, but will definitely check most people's boxes for average needs, imo.- Cost is higher than one might desire for just simple leisure shoes. But as an avid runner, the price is about average. However, they are usually on sale. My 1st set was around 40% off which dropped it from $70-something to $43, which was worth it for me. 2nd set was about 20% off. Winter holiday seems to be the best time for sales price.- Tread pattern is smooth and circular, instead of rigid and square/triangle, in case that matters to you (in regards to rock climbing etc)Overall I was surprisingly satisfied with this shoe model personally, but your mileage may vary.

Very nice shoe. Well built & appears durable. I especially loved the soft ankle.With high arch/high instep and wide forefoot, these shoes were not a good fit for me. Despite being men's running shoes, they felt like a women's B width. There is zero give the way they are stitched making them super tight across the forefoot at the base where lacing begins, and I mean cutting off circulation tight!It's clear to me that these shoes are made for heelstrikers with narrow feet:1) Exceptional shock absorbing heel cushioning that gives rather than squishes;2) Very little forefoot cushioning but provides good toe-off springboard action.What I found peculiar is that Nike did away with the 3rd gas tube running front to back with this model. No middle tube made my feet feel like they were being forced down midfoot—something that has actually resulted in stress fractures in the past—because I AM a supinator (underpronation, which means my natural gait strikes along the outside of my feet).They felt "corrective" so I would NOT recommend these to supinators, those with high arches and/or high instep, and definitely not to wide footers or wide forefooters, or forefoot strikers. Shin splints (along with other painful maladies) WILL occur—guaranteed!About me:  I was an avid fitness enthusiast years before I ever set foot in a commercial gym—and that was 35 years ago. Since then, I went on to become a personal trainer, taught aerobics for 20+ years, and have worked in numerous gyms—two of which I managed for some time.And for most of that time, I've been a Nike snob. However, their latest "improvements" on new models and elimination of older ones convey a simple message:  It's time to pack up my toys and move on. My groundpounders deserve compatible playmates.4 stars because I believe this to be a Nike typical, high-quality shoe. No 5th star because there is no mention or caution on the incredibly narrow width in a men's shoe, or the zero give with this new stitching, nor is there any information on the type of runner this shoe would—or would not benefit.
No fue el Color que seleccione, talla muy ajustado pero tiene una suave marcha

I’ve put a little over forty Florida-summer miles on the Nike Pegasus Trail 5 GORE-TEX, most of them in sideways rain, and they’ve already earned a reserved spot by the door. The Invisible Fit membrane keeps water out without giving that plastic-bag feel—my socks stay dry, and the shoe flexes like a regular trainer instead of a clunky winter boot.Underfoot, Nike’s new ReactX midsole brings road-shoe energy to mud, roots, and crushed-shell paths. I finish runs feeling bouncier than I have any right to on swampy routes. The outsole lugs and sticky rubber grab wet boardwalks and slick limestone with zero drama, so I’m not tip-toeing every time a puddle shows up.Little design touches seal the deal: an extended ankle collar that blocks sand and pine needles, a 3-D toe cap that shrugs off rocks, and a black/grey colorway that looks totally normal at the brewery post-run. The only trade-offs are the premium price—about $180—and slightly warmer feet on steamy days. Thin socks solve the latter; the waterproof peace of mind justifies the former.Bottom line: If you want one shoe that handles ankle-deep puddles yet still feels lively on dry pavement, the Pegasus Trail 5 GTX delivers. Consider me converted.

Review.review: I bought a pair of these shoes from a local store back in 2018 and loved how they fit my foot like a glove and felt so light on my feet for any kind of activity.  I went back to the same store a couple of years later to buy them again but they did not carry the same model.  I was very happy to find them on Amazon in many more beautiful colors than the two colors my initial pair were available in.  I had bought my first pair for $60 and feel that spending $100+ is rather expensive but it is also difficult to find running shoes that feel so good and I loved the bright color so I bought 3 more pairs to hopefully keep me in running shoes for the next several years.  My first pair has held up very well for me and have been washed several times so I feel good about the overall quality of the shoes.I have low arches and have had double bunion surgery many years ago so I usually exchange the insoles that come in shoes for insoles with an arch.  I did not need to do this for about three years with my first pair but lately began having some toe pain so I simply added added a gel arch under the regular insole and that easily solved the problem.I generally wear a 5 or 5.5 but a 6 fits me perfectly.  I also have narrow heels and these shoes gently hug my feel all around, giving a solid feeling of stability and lightness.

Review.review: This shoe is very comofrtable - very supportive - very durable - very stylish - and very cheap (for Nike)! You will not regret buying this shoe for just about any physical activity.

I purchased a pair after trying them on locally first. They are true to Nike size, comfortable and the built-in tongue is a plus for keeping it centered. But be cautious!!! After wearing them for 2 weeks, I'd estimate 6 miles of walking, they being to squeak. Not just a random squeak but a every time you take a step it bellows a eery squeak like the front door of a haunted house. Wildlife creatures are running for their lives when I attempt to walk my local natural trail. Hunters are angry that I scared off the 8 point buck from a mile away that they've been staying all season. I seriously can't hide at work. They know exactly where I am and when I'm walking down the halls. I'm 5' 10'', 185. It's not like I'm hurting the shoes but they are screaming for help with every step! I know, I know. It's just a inexpensive pair of shoes that some hard working child in Indonesia put blood and sweat into producing.  I really do appreciate every tear that they shed to glue them together, but they missed a spot. The most important spot. The spot that keep the shoe from squeaking. So to everyone that's has to hear me walk in them in the local Walmart and Target, I'm sorry! I wearing them for your enjoyment (with earbuds in my ears) so you can have a laugh for the day. One little star. You're welcome...

The first day I wore these, I went for a walk, and upon my walk was a nice big pile of dog doo doo. I was unaware of this big pile of doo-doo until it was too late. As I flew ybackward, I recall looking up at the sky, and to my surprise, I saw one of my brand new shoes flying by.  Next thing I knew I was lying there on the cold, hard sidewalk in such shock I layed there for what felt like forever. I slowly began to rise to my feet. I started to check myself for any injuries when suddenly I got a whiff of a nostril-burning foul smell. I reached my hand around to my back only to bring it right back abruptly.  I let out a loud scream followed by a gagging reaction to the dog poop that was now on my hand.  I ran to the grass and dropped to my knees I frantically began wiping my hand on the grass. As a tear ran down my face I remembered thinking can this day get any worse? Well, guess what it did! Behind me was a loud bark that scared me so much I jumped forward. I was now lying on the ground once more. As I got to my knees, I stood up quickly, eager to see the culprit that I believed to be the doggy doo doo bandit, but as I turned around to confront this demon, I promptly began to plead because in this dogs mouth was my other shoe I slowly began to approach this dog as I got close enough I made a daring move I tried to jump on the dog. I was unsuccessful with dog poop on my back, and with only one shoe on, I began to walk home sad and smelly.  Anyway I hope this helps your decision to buy these shoes or not

title: New Balance Men's 608 V5 Casual Comfort Cross Trainer
Customer_say: Customers find these shoes comfortable, well-made, and appreciate their long-lasting durability, noting they wear well for several years. They provide good arch support, particularly with inserts, and customers consider them excellent value for money. Review.review: I am thoroughly amazed and grateful these are just what I needed. My last pair of NB were walking shoes and was last bought 5 or 6 years ago. I do tons of walking but don't drag my feet so the soles don't wear fast and I don't let them get wet, but it was time to get a new pair. These new ones are perfect in every way, absolute comfort, roominess, but snug enough fit with a good amount of comfort padding inside, and they have the exact size dimensions of the last size 15's I had from 5 to 6 years ago, maybe a slight tad wider for even better comfort. I love that they don't pronate (tilt to one side from overly spongy soles) and are even more stable for the ankle than the last ones. They also don't have excessive heel height which is a huge problem for me in this trend of making heels too high since i have ankle issues and had to have surgery on my feet at age 4, so I was told my my orthopedic doctor my feet could not handle excess sloping, i.e., higher heels. In this regard, it reminds me of barefoot shoes with a flatter more even profile, but still with good arch support and still perfect shock absorbing comfort (not excessive since I can't handle excess arches). Glad I came across the perfect fit shoe for me, though there is one thing I hope will last and that is four of the shoelace eyelets in the middle were done differently for stylistic reasons: they are put through some type of fabric loop instead of the leather that the other holes are made to go through. If those loops have stitching that fails at some point then one would have to resort to drilling a hole into the leather where it normally would go through because they had to do this "cool" looking style feature. Who knows, maybe it will last okay. The price is great too, and hope they don't read this and raise it!
The fit is perfect. The size is exactly what it says it is they’re comfortable well-made and perfect for work shoes awesome value. Very good support good quality shoe.

These shoes were recommended to me by a podiatrist friend.  He said they were the best bargain out there for a quality tennis shoe that was actually good for your feet.  I can't agree more.  These have become my go to tennis shoe.  I walk about 15 miles a week on a wooded trail and these have held up over a year.  I have ordered several extra pairs for wearing around the house or with shorts in the summer.  They have all performed great and they are so comfortable.They have been called "Dad" shoes...well I am a Dad so no problem here.

It’s not the greatest show but i’m a sucker for an old man show. Comfortable and they fit my feet pretty well. Not to bad if you drive manual and want a shoe you can do that in too. They don’t look to bad in my opinion ether, solid buy for the price i got it at.

I bought this pair (12W) on August 23, 2024 and they have been great to wear on my daily walks. I have walked nearly 2 million steps since then in these shoes and they have great durability. I rotate them with another pair that I bought on Oct. 27, 2024, which has helped reduce the wear and tear. I removed the insoles and replaced them with PowerStep ProTech Control Orthotic Insoles and my feet feel great. The weight feels great on my feet and I don't have any foot fatigue after walking 10,000-20,000 steps in them. The 12W are now too wide for my feet but I still highly recommend this shoe. They are easy to clean and still look good on the outside. On the inside, I've worn the heel area out.I purchased the White/Team Royal version in size 12. I loved these as they fit better as I've been losing weight. The downside, the inside cushioning around the heel and ankle is gone. Worn out. I guess roughly 2,000,000 steps is a bit too much for this pair. Nonetheless, I do recommend these 608s.

Using these as outside work shoes since I walk over 7000 steps a day 6 days a week. The fit is perfect and they are true to size. The weight is about that of a casual hiking shoe; obviously not as light as a runner but not as heavy as my old work shoes. They feel both comfortable and tough at the same time. I’m hoping this will be the perfect combination for out door work where I don’t need a steel toe or necessarily strong water resistance.

I bought these Nike women’s sneakers because they look fantastic and feel really comfortable right out of the box. They’re lightweight, breathable, and work great for everyday wear. However, I use my sneakers both for workouts and long days at theme parks, and I found they don’t have quite enough heel support for my needs.As someone with plantar fasciitis, I rely heavily on strong heel cushioning, and these fall just a bit short in that area. Review.review: I ordered the Nike Metcon 6 Free about a week ago, and I’ve been pleasantly surprised with the performance right from the start. The shoes are extremely comfortable, offering a secure yet flexible fit that adapts well during both lifting and conditioning workouts. What stood out the most is how easy they were to break in—practically no adjustment period was needed. Within the first couple of sessions, they already felt like a natural extension of my training routine.The breathability is another strong point; the mesh upper keeps my feet cool even during long, high-intensity workouts. The stability in the heel gives confidence under heavier lifts, while the forefoot remains flexible enough for sprints, jumps, and dynamic movements. It’s a rare balance of support and comfort that makes the Metcon 6 Free versatile for both strength and functional training.Overall, this shoe delivers on all fronts: comfort, stability, and ease of use. If you want a training shoe that won’t slow you down with a long break-in period, the Metcon 6 Free is a solid choice.

Aside from comfort, being lightweight, and accommodating wider feet (unlike version 5 of the same sneaker), what really stands out about these is their versatility. I've never had a workout sneaker (metcon, running sneaker, powerlifting shoe) that has provided ample stability to perform barbell squats while also being comfortable, flexible, and lightweight enough to do an hour of cardio in. I wish that they lasted me slightly longer than 5 months, but considering what I put them through, these are great value for the money. I've purchased 5 total pairs of these and would recommend to anyone for almost any application.

The Nike Metcon 6 is an excellent all around athletic, workout shoe because it provides good cushioning, stability, breathability and flexibility. The Nike Metcon 6 feel much more stabile and confidently perform through a variety of activities. I started using these shoes on June 11, 2019.  At the time of this writing, that's almost 6 weeks. I'd suggest when you are reading these reviews you keep in mind how long the reviewer has been trying out the shoes; it can take several weeks to fully get used to a new shoe and reviewers who give hasty reviews (either good or bad) are not giving you the real picture.____________________In a nutshell, I got these shoes so I didn't have to spend a bunch of money on running shoes AND gym shoes. Nor clutter up my closet with too many pairs of shoes.  After using them for over a month, I am surprisingly satisfied.First off....I'm 6 foot and 175 lbs. My shoe size varies between 10.5 and 11 USA. My foot is slightly wide, with good arches.  I got these shoes in a size 11 and they fit great.  But not at first.....for the first 4-5 wearings they felt tight around the middle of my foot. At first I was disappointed and felt like they were not going to be a good fit. But after about a week of wearing them, they broke in just fine, and the fit now is great. I attribute the tight feeling to the plastic side braces that the shoestrings lace through: if you lace them overly tight, that will contribute to the uncomfortable feeling.My experience:  I have been running at least 3X a week for over 40 years. I've weightlifted and/or cross trained on a regular basis for over 30 years. I have been a personal trainer in the past (certified by ACE). I've run one of the toughest marathons in the world (Big Sur International Marathon), although I consider myself an average runner. I've used everything from cheap $40.00 Big 5 shoes for running to $130.00 Brooks. I've never bought a pair of shoes specifically for weight training or cross-fit workouts; I've always used running shoes for that.Here's how I wear them:- running 1-2 times a week. My average run is around 2.5 miles, but I've run up to 6 miles in them and they performed well. I would not recommend wearing these for regular runs longer than 3 miles because that's not what they are built for. I run mostly on pavement in California (moderate weather), although I just did a 6 mile run on trails in preparation for a 10K race later this month.  I feel like that was pushing the shoe to its limit, but it did fine.- stationary biking.- weight workouts. I do squats, standing barbell curls and overhead presses and these shoes are stable and don't shift. Of course you need to adjust the tightness of the laces depending on what you're doing and that's the cool thing about these - you can loosen them up a bit for non-critical exercises like stationary biking or tighten them up for running or squats.- kettle bell swings: again, they are stable and flexible.- burpees: this particular exercise really tests the stability, flexibility and shock-absorption of the shoe. If you've never done a burpee, I suggest Googling it to see what the movements are. In this exercise the shoe is subjected to squats, kick-outs where I land on the toes as I do a push-up, then they flex as I bring my feet back under me and jump up into the air, forcing them to not only be stable in launching me up but in absorbing my return to earth.I work out in these shoes 6 days a week.  The photo shows them as of today, nearly 6 weeks into daily use.  I typically run a couple days a week, do burpees 2x a week, weight lift 2-3 times a week, kettle bell swing 2x a week and do moderate cardio such as stationary bike 1-2 times a week.I didn't buy these to replace running shoes; I got them to use as short-distance runners and gym shoes. You shouldn't get these if you are doing multiple runs of more than 3 miles in a week - they aren't going to give the performance and protection you need for serious running. But for gym work, cross fit training and shorter runs, they are great and can replace expensive running shoes.You should note that the plastic shoe lace-ups/brackets on the side of the shoe have 3 positions. The position closest to your toes is the least secure/loosest fitting style. Each hole you lace going back towards your heel tightens the shoe's grip on your foot.  I use the middle lace hole for running and burpees and the stability is fine.  I lace it all the way to the back hole for squats to make sure the shoe doesn't slip.I've noted some reviewers say the "sock" collar around the ankle opening is loose.  I can say yes, it doesn't fit flush to your ankle when laced up, but that doesn't mean it slips! My foot is stable even if the sock appears to be loose-fitting. It isn't overly warm or hot, either (I was worried about that when I first got them).Again, if you're a serious runner I'd invest in good running shoes and use these for the gym. But if you're a casual runner of shorter distances and fit in weight training and/or cross-fit training, these shoes do a great job.I'll close by saying that in the last 20 years or so I've gotten wiser and have spent more money on running shoes, and with these shoes I've gotten my first shoe specially designed for cross-training also. I am happy with the performance of the shoes so far. I've never had a serious running injury, partially out of luck but largely because as my joints have gotten older I've used better shoes.  Good luck and good health to you!

Review.review: These shoes arrived on time and in perfect condition. They are a fabulous fit at size 8 and I use them daily at the gym. I am a lifelong NIKE customer and this quality is on point with the Nike brand. Very good heel cushion as I have some slight heel pain to deal with. Four stars for the design of the shoe laces. I have thin ankles and the shoe slips unless you thread the shoelaces through the second loophole at the top of the shoe lace row. I realize it is a 'me' problem and not a shoe problem - but thought it would be helpful to share how I solved this problem to make the shoe work for me. Also, the shoe is lightweight and cool - the bottoms are light colored. If you live in a very hot climate (like VEGAS) the asphalt is very very hot. If you wear a dark sole shoe it absorbs the heat and makes your feet so very hot. I would recommend wearing a thinner sock with this shoe if you are a runner/walker. It seems to enhance the comfort. Excellent shoe for the gym and very stylish!

True to size and very comfortable. I wear a 10.5; ordered this size and they fit very well. I have walked around in them for hours at a time and they did not cause any pain or discomfort. I originally wanted a black, but this color has grown on me, as it really does go with a variety of outfits. The style is nice and so far, I am getting value for money.

I bought this for cross training/HIIT and weight lifting to replace my old Nike. I paid 48 dollars for the grey color, which is perfect for my needs. This shoe is super light (I don't lile bulky shoes) and can feel like barefoot at times. It performs really well on body combat classes for high kicks and jumps, it does well on weight training, and it is almost good for HIIT. My only negative for it is that it has very limited lateral support for HIIT training, and that it feels a bit too wide/roomy for my narrow-ish feet (I'm a 7, 117lbs/5'5" and bought a 7). Also it slides backwards slightly for lunges, but not for squats. It also slides backwords for planks, so I need to place my feet on the mat to stay put.I did some light treadmill running in these and they worked for the lower intensity/short runs as well.Overall, I reccomend this shoe. If it's for walking / kicking around, these are super light and comfy and cute. If it's for cross training, these offer a very lightweight, responsive shoe (as opposed to the bulky ones with added whistles and bells) and it may surprise you that you will pick them every time for a quick gym workout.

​Run, Don't Walk, Away from These "Nikes"​If you're in the market for a new pair of running shoes, I have a recommendation for you: run as fast as you can in the opposite direction from these. I don't know who made these, but I'm pretty sure their product development meeting went something like this: "Okay, we need a running shoe that looks like a Nike, but is it a Nike? Absolutely not. Will it support your foot? No. Can you run in it? You can try. Should you try? Probably not."​The lack of support is truly a work of art, a masterpiece of structural failure. It feels less like I'm wearing a running shoe and more like I'm running on two very stylish, foot-shaped pillows. You know how some shoes have a heel cup to keep your foot in place? These have a heel suggestion, a gentle nudge that basically says, "Your foot should probably stay here, but hey, if it wants to slip around, that's cool too."​And let's talk about the midsole. I'm not a podiatrist, but I'm pretty sure a shoe's midsole is supposed to provide a stable foundation, not an expanding one. These shoes have a tragic flaw: the midsole has decided to spread out like a happy-go-lucky house guest who's gotten a little too comfortable on the couch. Every time I take a step, I can feel the shoe itself surrendering to the laws of physics, widening and flattening out under the sheer weight of my disappointment.​I waited too long to return them, a classic rookie mistake. I was too optimistic, hoping that with each run, they would somehow magically transform into the supportive shoes they were pretending to be. They did not. Instead, they just got worse, which is honestly impressive. So, would I purchase them again? Not unless I'm training for a clown marathon where oversized, floppy footwear is a requirement. Would I recommend them? Only to my worst enemy. You've been warned.

Review.review: Very comfortable and stylish shoes. This is my first pair of the X PRL Path sneakers but I am very happy with the quality and fit.The cloud foam is very soft and comfortable on your feet when walking and standing. They are very light weight, durable and slip resistant. They do seem to be more narrow than my other shoes but thankfully they still fit me perfectly. I wear size 11 and they do fit to size length wise.I purchased these shoes in Black/Lucid Lemon and I absolutely love the bold Yellow color. It's even brighter than in the pictures. They definitely stand out! I have a lot of Adidas shoes but this is my first of this color, and they go perfectly with my Adidas Tiro 3 stripe black/lucid lemon shirt!The price was also a great value for Adidas brand shoes. I have only worn them a few times, so will update if anything changes, but so far I am very satisfied and have already recieved a compliment on them!

I gave these sneakers as a birthday present, and they were a total hit. As soon as my partner opened the box, their face lit up — they loved the style, and it was exactly the vibe I was going for: clean, modern, and easy to wear with pretty much anything.They put them on right away and said they were super comfortable. The fit was just right, and they felt sturdy without being too bulky. Breathable, supportive — basically, everything you'd want in a sneaker.

I bought these for my son because he has several adidas outfits and he needed something comfortable.  So, we kill 2 birds with one stone.  There's no complaints from him and he wears them often.  These are great for semi wide feet and causes no blisters, but he does wear socks with them.  It is a nice, clean and versatile shoe.

I’ve worn a lot of different adidas sneakers over the years, and these X_PLR Paths are a really solid option if you’re looking for something casual and lightweight. They’re comfortable right out of the box — no break-in time needed — and the Cloudfoam cushioning does a good job for everyday walking and running errands.The color looks great in person — just a little more muted than it appeared online, which honestly I liked even better once I saw them. They’re really easy to pair with jeans or joggers.One heads-up: they’re more of a casual/lifestyle shoe than a hardcore running shoe. Fine for light workouts, but if you’re planning serious running, you might want something a little more performance-focused.Overall, really comfortable and clean-looking for everyday wear.

This is my 3rd pair of this model (Interact Run). This is my 2nd pair of the white/day-glo green logo model. The shoe just looks great. I get a lot of compliments on its looks.Fit: I wear a 9.5 Wide, typical shoe size. However, on my work out shoes I usually go up to a size 10. I need the extra toe box width. This size 10 feels a little tight to begin with, but it does stretch out pretty quickly. I did order a 10.5 on one pair and it opened up the toe box, but is a little loose.Durability: The tread is not very deep, so I find that I am wearing the grooves out in my major contact areas pretty quickly. I am getting about 90 days of everyday workout use before the certain areas are slick. The shoe is still very serviceable, so it gets relegated to a walking or casual shoe.Value: I could sometimes get this shoe for under $60. That for me is a great value. Similar shoes go for around $120 in my experience.I would highly recommend for an indoor gym / cross training shoe

title: Under Armour Boys Grade School Assert 10
Customer_say: Customers find these shoes to be good quality, comfortable, and durable enough to last throughout the school year. Review.review: I recently purchased the Under Armour Kids' Grade School Assert 10 Sneakers for my child, and they are excellent! These sneakers are lightweight yet supportive, making them perfect for everyday wear, sports, and outdoor activities. The breathable mesh upper keeps feet cool, while the cushioned midsole provides comfort and shock absorption during running or play.The sneakers also have a durable rubber outsole that provides excellent traction, reducing the risk of slips during active play. The sleek design and modern style appeal to kids, and the shoes fit true to size, making them easy to wear for extended periods.Overall, the Assert 10 combines comfort, durability, and style, making it a reliable choice for active kids. They hold up well after repeated wear and are easy to clean, making them a great value for parents.Pros:Lightweight, breathable mesh upperCushioned midsole for comfort and shock absorptionDurable rubber outsole with good tractionSleek and modern design appealing to kidsTrue-to-size fit and easy to cleanCons:Minimal color options in some sizesLaces may require supervision for younger childrenOverall: The Under Armour Kids' Grade School Assert 10 Sneakers are comfortable, durable, and stylish, perfect for active kids who need reliable everyday footwear. Highly recommended!

title: Nike Men's Free Metcon 6 Workout Shoes
Customer_say: Customers find these workout shoes comfortable, stylish, and lightweight, with good stability that provides confidence during heavier lifts. Moreover, they appreciate the quality, with one customer noting the sock liner design for ankle support, and consider them the best all-purpose workout shoe. However, the fit receives mixed feedback - while some find them snug to put on, others mention they're hard to get on and off. Additionally, opinions about size vary, with some finding them suitable for wide feet while others note they run a bit small.

Review.review: I ordered the Nike Metcon 6 Free about a week ago, and I’ve been pleasantly surprised with the performance right from the start. The shoes are extremely comfortable, offering a secure yet flexible fit that adapts well during both lifting and conditioning workouts. What stood out the most is how easy they were to break in—practically no adjustment period was needed. Within the first couple of sessions, they already felt like a natural extension of my training routine.The breathability is another strong point; the mesh upper keeps my feet cool even during long, high-intensity workouts. The stability in the heel gives confidence under heavier lifts, while the forefoot remains flexible enough for sprints, jumps, and dynamic movements. It’s a rare balance of support and comfort that makes the Metcon 6 Free versatile for both strength and functional training.Overall, this shoe delivers on all fronts: comfort, stability, and ease of use. If you want a training shoe that won’t slow you down with a long break-in period, the Metcon 6 Free is a solid choice.
Lightweight and very comfortable. Fit is great.

This version of the Free Metcon (Version 6) is by far the best all-purpose workout shoe that I've ever used. I really put my workout sneakers through the ringer; using them 7-days a week for weight training and cardio (3.5 miles/day of incline treadmill). Aside from comfort, being lightweight, and accommodating wider feet (unlike version 5 of the same sneaker), what really stands out about these is their versatility. I've never had a workout sneaker (metcon, running sneaker, powerlifting shoe) that has provided ample stability to perform barbell squats while also being comfortable, flexible, and lightweight enough to do an hour of cardio in. I wish that they lasted me slightly longer than 5 months, but considering what I put them through, these are great value for the money. I've purchased 5 total pairs of these and would recommend to anyone for almost any application.

The Nike Metcon 6 is an excellent all around athletic, workout shoe because it provides good cushioning, stability, breathability and flexibility. Before purchasing these shoes for my Gold'sFit workout class, I used running shoes, but running shoes did not provide enough lateral support and stability during lifts and doing side to side movement. The Nike Metcon 6 feel much more stabile and confidently perform through a variety of activities. When I started looking at other people's shoes in the gym, I was surprised how many also also chose the Nike Metcon.

I am very happy with this purchase. I intend to keep the shoes & use them for the gym and PT. I am unsure If I will use them on the court for Pickleball however, or other sports however.  They seem more aesthetic than sports effective.  There is not much arch support. They are the same caliber as the Cole Haan  tennis shoes which are actually good & much better than Dooney & Burke which are definitely aesthetically designed.  The leather on the Nike is EXCELLENT.  Much better than the brands I just mentioned.  I could tell by the way they buckled  to conform to the crease of my foot on the first wear without breaking. They will definitely hold up a lot longer than most brands I have had. I am happy with the fit & was able to adjust the laces to fit the extra width of my feet satisfactorily which is not always the case.  Some brands cut the width short @ the base & before letting the shoe widen out to save $.  Nike did not do this & I was very happy with being able to adjust the fit.  The heel padding is EXCELLENT ALSO. This shoe fit durability, quality, sizing, fit, heel padding, leather quality, ease of cleaning, true to description & aesthetically pleasing! The only reason I did not give it a 5 is that These qualities were all so good that the arch support did not compare to their definite 5 rating.  So what could have been an overall 5 shoe in every category got uncharacteristically, almost unfairly downgraded to a 4 because of one  category…. Arch support.  If all shoes could say that they would be 5’s. I guess this is a rather critical review if all the categories are 5 except one.  I hope this is helpful.

Review.review: These Under Armour sneakers quickly became one of my favorite pairs of shoes. They’re very comfortable right out of the box, with good cushioning and support that make them easy to wear all day. On top of that, the design is sleek and modern, so they work just as well for casual wear as they do for workouts.I also appreciate the variety of styles and sizes that Under Armour offers. It made it easy to find the right fit and a look I really like. The build quality feels solid too — the stitching, materials, and overall construction seem durable, which gives me confidence they’ll hold up well over time.Overall, a great mix of comfort, style, and durability. Definitely recommend these sneakers!

These sneakers are a reflection of quality. They're a great product, and for me, what stands out most is their comfort. They're very comfortable, especially in the back of the foot, which is very padded. They're also made with excellent materials and seem durable for the long term. Overall, the sneakers are well-made and very light. They don't feel heavy at all; all the details are well-cared for.As for aesthetics, it depends more on each person's personal taste, but I loved the very modern and youthful design. In general, products from this brand tend to have good designs. As for the size, it was exactly what I ordered. I think you should follow the advice given in the product description. For example, I'm a size 10.5, but they advise ordering one size larger than your normal size. So, I ordered size 11.5, and the truth is, they fit me very well. For my first online shoe purchase, it was a good idea, since that's one of the disadvantages of buying shoes online: not being able to test if they fit properly.The price I paid for what I got was fair, and I would definitely buy them again.

Review.review: Perfect for my wide forefoot and high arch. The fit is snug but feels comfortable. I'd rather have this close fit and support than a loosey-goosey fit that I was getting in the Saucony Excursion terrain shoe in the same size. I also like the heel cuff, the exursion was skimpy on the padding and got lumpy too quickly. These are overall very nicely made and nice looking.

I was hoping they would stretch out over time but they're hurting my toes too much and I can't stand to wear them.
These sneakers are my go-to. So comfortable and have great cushion. There's nothing I can't do in these sneakers!

I have worn Saucony running shoes for 40 years, and have never gone wrong with a pair. My first pair was orange and garish, but on sale at an outlet. I was a poor college student training for a 1/2 marathon, and bought what I could afford. From then on it was love at first step. Like all the other Saucony shoes in my past, the Saucony Women's Cohesion 14 Road Running Shoe (what a mouthful) is a delight. I normally wear a women's size 9, but have a wide foot, so ordered a 9.5 US in this shoe. Good fit, good arch support, no rub at the back of the heel, nice stability against ankle roll on irregular terrain, nice sole cushion for heel strike and follow through, good flexibility at the bend of the metatarsal-toe joints. Good breathability...no sweaty feet after prolonged use (I prefer wearing socks). I'm not the fastest runner/walker on the block anymore, but these shoes still allow me to get out there and try. Plus, the black/grey/blue color scheme is attractive, even when wearing with casual slacks or jeans.Update, several years later: My previous pair of Saucony Cohesion 14 shoes are ready to retire. After regular use for several years, the front sole is beginning to peel back and my great toes are pushing forward in the toe box while running, wearing this area thin. I lace the shoes loose to help widen the toe box, and agree with other reviewers that the Saucony toe box on this shoe is more narrow than in past decades (I've worn Saucony brand for running since early 1980's). To adjust for the narrower design and different manufacturer, I ordered up from a size 9.5 to a size 10. I was skeptical that a size 10 would work because I normally wear a 9.5 running shoe. Right out of the box the new size 10's feel ok. My great toes are a full index-finger width back from the front end of the toe (see attached photo). This is comfortable. However the heel area is a bit loose compared to the size 9.5. I wear socks with these shoes, but as yet don't know if the heel will slip when running uneven terrain. The photos show the old size 9.5 (grey/blue) shoes compared to the new size 10 (blue/light blue) shoes. The length difference is barely perceptible, and the new shoes show the slimmer toe box. Just be aware that you may want to size up or go to a wide size for comfort. Still a good shoe for the price.
